TEXT.English: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Gunships[COLOR_REVERT] are able to enter [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Jungle[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Rainforest[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Marsh[COLOR_REVERT], cannot capture enemy cities or units, don't receive defensive bonuses, ignore terrain movement costs, can withdraw from combat, have a combat bonus against [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Armored Units[COLOR_REVERT], have a flank attack against [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Siege Weapons[COLOR_REVERT] and begin with the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Amphibious[COLOR_REVERT] promotion.

TEXT.English: The [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Agent[COLOR_REVERT], the American replacement for the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Spy[COLOR_REVERT], can perform [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Install Regime[COLOR_REVERT], a special espionage mission that, if successful, make the target civilization your vassal.

TEXT.English: Employing spies to aid against the British during the Revolution, the United States has used its agents since even before its international recognition. In 1947, Preseident Truman created the Central Intelligence Agency to centralize American international espionage. Since then, agents have acted in counts missions across the world, especially in Latin America. In attempts to solidify American hegemony, covert operations even overthrew entire governments to further the interests of the United States.

TEXT.English: The [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Longship[COLOR_REVERT], the Viking replacement for the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Heavy Galley[COLOR_REVERT] has two extra movement points, can bombard city defenses, has two cargo spaces and begins with the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Disengage I[COLOR_REVERT] promotion.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Longships (aka longboats) were sea vessels made and used by the Vikings from the Nordic countries for trade, commerce, exploration, and warfare during the Viking Age although scientific analysis of the oak timber shows at least one well known ship was built in Dublin, Ireland. The longship's design evolved over many years, beginning in the Stone Age with the invention of the umiak and continuing up to the 9th century with the Nydam and Kvalsund ships. The longship appeared in its complete form between the 9th and 13th centuries. The character and appearance of these ships have been reflected in Scandinavian boat-building traditions until today. The particular skills and methods employed in making longships are still used world wide, often with modern adaptations. They were all made out of wood, with cloth flags and had lots of details and carvings on the hull.
